column2: Faced with unclear or ambiguous requirements, I still find myself working hard to get the code to do exactly what's expected.
column3: I don't feel comfortable calling something "done" until I've thoroughly tested my code, including edge cases. It is a top priority for me.
column4: Discovering even a minor functional bug in my released code feels like a significant failure.
column5: I often profile or analyze my code to find opportunities to make it run faster or use less memory, even if it already works.
column6: When choosing libraries or algorithms, I actively consider their impact on speed and resource consumption.
column7: I prioritize writing code that is clear and easy for other developers (or my future self) to understand.
column8: I consciously structure my code (e.g., using clear patterns, keeping functions focused) to make future modifications or extensions easier.
column9: Taking the time to add helpful comments or documentation to explain complex or non-obvious parts of the code is important to me.
column10: I make it a point to follow established security best practices and guidelines relevant to my work.
column11: When making architectural decisions, I consider how easily the system could be expanded to handle significantly more traffic
column12: If test results look bad, I will openly share these findings- even if it might reflect poorly on me or my team.
column13: I willingly set aside time to help less experienced teammates understand tricky code or concepts, even when it slows down my own tasks.
column14: I would spend extra time or resources checking for potential bias  (bias meaning a consistent inaccuracy or skew in how the code processes or interprets data) in my code, even if it wasn’t strictly required.
column15: For a high-stakes system (e.g., determining eligibility for life-saving medical treatment), I believe fairness (ensuring that individuals or groups are not disadvantaged based on race, gender, disability, etc.) checks are absolutely crucial, even if they add delay to development.
column16: I’d be willing to delay a product launch if I suspect user data isn’t well-protected.
column17: Even for a ‘simple’ analytics feature, I worry about privacy leaks and try to guard user data.
column18: When project pressure rises, I actively work to maintain communication with teammates respectful to keep team morale high.
column19: When something goes wrong, it’s usually everyone’s responsibility to fix it, not just the person who wrote the code.
column20: I sometimes soften or withhold critical feedback during code reviews to avoid hurting a teammate’s feelings and keep our working relationships positive
column21: If my manager asked me to implement a feature I believe is morally questionable, I’d seriously consider refusing, regardless of the consequences.
column22: I think about the potential negative impacts of my software on society (like spreading misinformation) before deciding how to implement features.
column23: If implementing a profitable feature raises concerns about negative impacts on a specific user group, I’d still work on it, if it's part of the company's requirements.

column27: Data Science/ ML Engineer/ AI Engineer
column43: If it's important, then i'll prioritize correctness
if the project is critical most of the times it means that the project has a big impact on the customer, so I want ensure we are protecting customers' privacy

In projects that are defined to be more critical, I tend to prioritize the correctness and maintainability higher. If the schedule is tight, good relationships become a bit less prioritized - I defend my opinions more strongly. Broader social impact and privacy would always be a top priority, no matter how critical the project (but in my current work they don't tend to play a major issue anyway, since my company does not really have any contact with users...)

column27: Data Science/ ML Engineer/ AI Engineer

column43: If the project is important to the organization it gives me energy and get me the feeling impactfull which leads to more correctness maintainability

column43: On highly critical projects I would prioritize correctness over other things. On low critical projects other considerations have more say.

column27: Data Science/ ML Engineer/ AI Engineer
column43: The higher the project’s criticality, the more I favor reliability and risk mitigation over speed or innovation.
when it's super critical I'll prioritize correctness over other values

column27: Data Science/ ML Engineer/ AI Engineer
Data Science/ ML Engineer/ AI Engineer
column43: I believe that when it becomes bigger, then the feeling of responsibility is greater, and therefore all of the mentioned before - privacy, correctness, fairness, etc.. are getting stronger influence on me and my work attitude

It's not just "criticality", each project comes with requirements that should be met. Some projects needs to handle high scale, some need to be very accurate, some need to deliver real time insight but accuracy can be lower, so I would say that values are prioritized based on requirements.
The more critical the project is, the more you prioritize safety, robustness, and correctness over speed, cost, or convenience.
If the feature Im working on is simply visual or unrelated to the test of the website then Im fine with releasing it even if not 100% as planned (but still works well).

column43: As the project is more critical, the more I prioritize correctness over fairness and privacy. The more time I have, I will also invest in documentation, maintenance, and lasty privacy and fairness as well.

column42: I'd add efficiency and cost-effectiveness explicitly—sometimes that's the deciding factor.
column43: In high-criticality projects, efficiency and correctness become central. I’m pragmatic; I shift towards stricter testing and security checks more than usual.

column42: User accessibility considerations might be a good addition.
column43: Critical projects heighten my focus on fairness, respect, and preventing user harm. My ethical concerns grow even stronger when stakes rise.
The higher the stakes, the more I prioritize fairness, accuracy, and social impact. It's essential to mitigate risks of harm or bias in critical projects.
